questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she sustained a fall 3 hours ago. The patient was walking down the stairs when she lost her balance and fell onto the right side of her body. She did not lose consciousness. She has nausea, pain in her right hip, and has not been able to walk since the fall. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteoporosis. She lives with her daughter. She is independent in all of her activities of daily living and instrumental activities of daily living. She walks 2 miles every other day. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. Current medications include atorvastatin, ramipril, metformin, and a multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. She appears pale. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right leg seems shorter than the left and is rotated externally. Pulses are intact in both lower extremities. Palpation of the right hip causes severe pain and the range of motion is limited. An x-ray of the right hip is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonweightbearing would be appropriate management for an older, nonambulatory patient who has poor physical function and is not a candidate for operative management. Since this patient was physically active and independent in her activities of daily living as well as instrumental activities of daily living with a walking routine, nonweightbearing conservative management is not an appropriate option here.

B) INCORRECT:

External fixation may be appropriate for unstable polytrauma patients in whom more critical interventions are prioritized, in patients with vascular injury, or in patients with severe open fractures. This patient's presentation is consistent with an isolated closed intertrochanteric femoral fracture. In addition, as her lower extremity pulses are intact bilaterally, she has no signs of vascular injury. Therefore, management with external fixation is inappropriate for this patient.
Image Description:

External fixation is a method of immobilizing a fracture using devices (e.g., pins, screws, etc) that are secured outside the skin (in contrast to internal fixation, in which the devices are placed completely inside the body).

C) CORRECT:

Definitive surgical treatment is indicated for active, independent patients. First-line surgical treatment for a stable intertrochanteric fracture is internal fixation using either an intramedullary nail or a dynamic hip screw.

Femoral fractures are only considered a surgical emergency if there is vascular compromise, which is limb-threatening. This patient does not require emergent surgery.
Image Description:

Osteosynthesis of an intertrochanteric fracture using a gamma locking nail: An intramedullary nail is placed directly into the bone marrow through the greater trochanter and held in position using a distal fixation screw. A lag screw is then placed through the nail, which enters the neck and head of the femur. This nail also allows for compression (weight-bearing) of the fracture site. The combination of intramedullary nail and lag screw resembles the Greek letter "γ" (gamma), which is why it is called a gamma locking nail.

D) INCORRECT:

Early weightbearing with physical therapy would be appropriate management for someone with soft tissue injury. However, as this patient has the hallmark clinical signs and x-ray findings consistent with intertrochanteric fracture, early mobility would be inappropriate. Without appropriate prior fixation of the fracture, ambulation could displace the fracture and lead to malunion or nonunion. This physically active patient needs fixation of her fracture first, followed by ambulation with physical therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Total hip replacement may be considered for injuries of both the femur and the pelvis, or for femoral neck fractures in older patients in which arthritic changes or poor bone quality affect the acetabulum. However, this patient has an isolated intertrochanteric fracture rather than a fracture of the femoral neck or pelvis.
Image Description:

(1) Removal of the damaged femoral head from the acetabulum and resection of the femoral head and neck along the line between the greater and the lesser trochanter (red line)
(2) Enlargement of the acetabulum and the medullary cavity of the femur
(3) Insertion of the prosthesis stem into the femoral canal and insertion of the artificial socket and inlay into the widened acetabulum
4) Reduction of the prosthetic head into the prosthetic socket

F) INCORRECT:

Hip hemiarthroplasty is the appropriate management for a femoral head fracture close enough to the hip joint for the free femoral bone fragment to likely have compromised blood supply, resulting in avascular necrosis. This would also be appropriate for an older patient with a femoral neck fracture that is displaced or has poor bone quality. However, as this patient has an intertrochanteric fracture, she will likely only need arthroplasty as second-line treatment or if the fracture is significantly unstable.

G) INCORRECT:

Traction screws are used to counteract the opposing pull of the thigh muscles on bone fragments. This serves to both prevent displacement of the fracture and to decrease bleeding and pain. This treatment method, combined with other conservative treatments (e.g., stabilization using a splint, analgesia), would be appropriate in older patients with too many comorbidities to safely undergo surgery, or in very young patients. However, since this older patient is relatively healthy and active, she is a safe candidate for definitive surgical management.
questions.hint: This patient's x-ray shows an intertrochanteric fracture.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which she was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A dashboard injury can result in a femoral neck fracture, which manifests with hip and groin pain. A displaced femoral neck fracture also results in limb shortening. However, the leg of a patient with a femoral neck fracture would be either in the neutral position or externally rotated, not internally rotated.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with an anterior hip dislocation may present with pain in the groin, and a mild flexion deformity of the hip. However, the leg would be lengthened, externally rotated, and mildly abducted.

C) INCORRECT:

Femoral shaft fractures usually occur following high-energy trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accidents) and may manifest with shortening of the injured limb and leg pain. However, the pain is usually localized to the mid-thigh, and the thigh would be swollen.

D) CORRECT:

Posterior hip dislocation is the most common type of hip dislocation (approx. 90% of cases) and classically occurs following high-energy trauma, in which a posteriorly directed force (e.g., dashboard during a motor vehicle accident) is directed towards the hip. The affected leg is typically shortened, mildly flexed, internally rotated, and adducted. Given the considerable amount of force required for posterior hip dislocation, associated fractures of the femoral head or the acetabulum are common.

Hip dislocation is diagnosed with the help of an AP view x-ray of the hip. In the case of posterior hip dislocation, the femoral head on the dislocated side usually appears smaller than the normal side, the lesser trochanter may not be visible as a result of internal hip joint rotation, and Shenton's line is typically disrupted.
Image Description:

Dashboard injuries occur when a force is directed posteriorly towards an internally rotated, flexed, and adducted hip. Potentially resulting damage includes posterior dislocation of the hip; damage to the posterior cruciate ligament of the knee; fracture of the acetabulum, femoral head, or patella; and sciatic nerve injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ring fractures usually occur following high-energy trauma (e.g., road traffic accident) and may present with hip or groin pain and leg-length discrepancy. However, there is no evidence of pelvic instability, perineal hemorrhage, or swelling on physical examination. Moreover, in a patient with pelvic ring fracture, the limbs are usually externally (rather than internally) rotated.
questions.hint: This patient has a typical dashboard injury.

questions.text: X-rays of the pelvis, right hip, and both knee caps are performed. The pelvic ring, including the right acetabulum, is intact. The knee caps are normal. An x-ray of the right hip shows posterior dislocation. The femoral neck and shaft on the right side are both intact and there are no signs of a fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up in two weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation is not recommended in this patient because prompt treatment is required to avoid further complications. Additionally, open reduction is only indicated if closed reduction fails, when the dislocation is associated with femoral neck or head fracture, or if bony fragments/tissue are found within the joint space, and none of these conditions apply.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate treatment is indicated in patients with posterior hip dislocation. Open reduction, however, is only indicated if closed reduction fails, dislocation is associated with femoral neck or head fracture, or bony fragments/tissue are found within the joint space, and none of these conditions apply.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation is not recommended in this patient because prompt treatment is required to avoid further complications. Although this patient's dislocation needs to be reduced, it should be done as soon as possible and not as an elective procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in two weeks is not a recommended strategy because spontaneous resolution is very unlikely to occur. The risk of complications (e.g., osteonecrosis, nerve injury) warrants further treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Emergency closed reduction, usually carried out under procedural sedation, is the recommended treatment for simple posterior hip dislocation. This intervention should be performed as soon as possible (usually within 6 hours) to improve blood flow to the femoral head and thus minimize the risk of complications (e.g., osteonecrosis, degenerative joint disease).
questions.hint: Posterior hip dislocation requires prompt treatment to avoid further complications.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of severe pain in his groin after a fall. Two hours ago, he slipped on a wet rug and fell on his right side. The daughter says he “could not get up on his own” and can hardly walk. There was no trauma to the head or upper limbs. Medical history is remarkable for hypothyroidism. His medications are levothyroxine and a fish oil supplement. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a shortened right lower limb in external rotation; there are no visible bruises. Range of motion of the right hip is severely limited due to pain. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A femoral neck fracture should be suspected in an older individual who presents with groin pain, inability to walk, decreased range of motion, and an externally rotated and shortened leg after a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. Because the fracture site is intracapsular, there is typically little bruising. This patient's x-ray confirms the diagnosis and shows a right-sided femoral neck fracture with complete displacement of the bone fragments. Immediate management of a femoral neck fracture is essential to prevent severe complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head and sciatic nerve injury. In patients < 60 years of age with nondisplaced fractures, open reduction with internal fixation is recommended; patients > 80 years with displaced fractures will require primary arthroplasty, typically total hip replacement.

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior hip dislocation is typically associated with internal, rather than external rotation of the affected limb and most commonly develops as a result of high-speed trauma (e.g., dashboard injury), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows normal joint congruency between the right femoral head and the acetabulum, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

The femoral head (solid line) is displaced superior and lateral to the acetabulum (dashed line). The dislocated head appears smaller than the contralateral femoral head. The lesser trochanter (LT) projects over the femoral shaft as a result of internal rotation of the femur.

The radiographic findings are consistent with posterior dislocation of the hip. The dislocated head is closer to the x-ray detector than the contralateral head and is perceived as smaller due to the effect of geometric magnification. In the case of anterior dislocation, the lesser trochanter is typically more visible as a result of external rotation and the femoral head appears larger than the contralateral head.

GT: greater trochanter

C) INCORRECT:

A femoral head fracture typically occurs as a result of posterior hip dislocation due to high-energy trauma (e.g., dashboard injury), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows an intact femoral head, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

Anteroposterior x-ray of the pelvis: A femoral head fracture (green area and green line) in combination with a medial fracture of the femoral neck (angle 75°, Pauwels' classification) can be seen in this x-ray image. This fracture combination (femoral head fracture and medial fracture of the femoral neck) is categorized as Pipkin III according to the Pipkin classification.

D) INCORRECT:

A pelvic fracture typically presents with pelvic instability, local ecchymosis (e.g., in the inguinal, scrotal region), and other findings of concomitant pelvic organ injuries (e.g., high-riding prostate due to urethral injury, hematuria due to bladder injury), none of which are seen here. In addition, pelvic fractures usually occur as a result of high-speed trauma (e.g., due to car/motorcycle accident), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. Lastly, this patient's x-ray shows an intact pelvis, which is inconsistent with pelvic fracture.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

The right hemipelvis is displaced superiorly, compatible with disruption of the sacroiliac joint (indicated by dashed lines and double-headed arrow). Bilateral pubic ramus fractures are also present (indicated by arrowheads).

E) INCORRECT:

This was a good option to consider because an intertrochanteric fracture commonly occurs in elderly individuals after a fall on the hip and manifests with an externally rotated and shortened leg, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, this type of hip fracture usually manifests with significant ecchymosis because, unlike in this patient, the fracture site is extracapsular. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows a femoral fracture above the intertrochanteric line, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

AP radiograph of the right hip: Because of the low quality, the structure of the greater trochanter (T) is poorly defined; the dotted line shows a possible contour. A radiolucent fracture gap is located in between the greater and lesser trochanter and at the base of the lesser trochanter (t), possibly indicating an intertrochanteric femoral fracture.
questions.hint: This patient will most likely require total hip replacement surgery.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of left groin pain. The pain started when he rotated his upper body to throw his opponent on the ground during a wrestling competition at school. He has no history of hip or knee injuries. His past medical history is significant for asthma, for which he takes daily inhaled corticosteroids. He does not smoke cigarettes but reports occasionally drinking beer and smoking marijuana with some of his friends after school. He is at the 65th percentile for height, 90th percentile for weight, and 69th percentile for BMI. On physical examination, the left leg is slightly flexed at the hip and externally rotated. Range of motion of the left hip is decreased. There is tenderness over the groin and medial aspect of the upper thigh that worsens with hip flexion and rotation. An x-ray of the hip is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A trochanter minor fracture is most commonly seen in physically active young adults, particularly those who participate in high-impact sports such as wrestling. A sudden, forceful contraction of the iliopsoas muscle pulls the lesser trochanter away from the femoral shaft, resulting in lesser trochanter apophysis avulsion. This can cause significant groin and medial thigh pain and swelling, and reduced range of motion in the affected hip that worsens with hip flexion and rotation. The fracture is typically self-limiting and managed with conservative measures (e.g., rest, ice, physical therapy). Surgical repair is required for fractures with displacement of > 1 cm.

B) INCORRECT:

Avascular necrosis of the femoral head should be considered in patients with groin pain and a history of corticosteroid use. The pain is also worsened by flexion and rotation of the affected hip. However, an x-ray of the hip would typically show cystic and sclerotic changes in the femoral head, subchondral collapse, and flattening of the femoral head.
Image Description:

X-ray right hip (AP view)

The articular surface of the femoral head is irregular (black dotted line) and the underlying bone is heterogeneous (green overlay) as a result of osteonecrosis. A zone of sclerosis (red overlay) is present along the interface with normal bone.

C) INCORRECT:

Femoral neck fractures manifest with sudden onset groin pain, an externally rotated leg, and decreased range of motion at the hip, and an x-ray may show a displaced bony fragment. However, femoral neck fractures typically occur following high-energy trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accidents, falls from great heights) and an x-ray would show affection of the femoral neck, unlike the lesion seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Deformity of the proximal right femur is the result of a displaced fracture through the femoral neck. The greater trochanter (GT; green overlay) projects over the femoral neck on this image and obscures the fracture line. Osteopenia and degenerative changes in the pelvis are also seen.

Dashed outline and H: Femoral head; LT: Lesser trochanter

D) INCORRECT:

Adductor strain is common in athletes and can manifest with sudden onset groin pain and tenderness over the medial aspect of the thigh. However, a hip x-ray would not show pathological findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is the most common hip disorder in adolescents, particularly affecting obese males. While the condition usually develops gradually over several weeks or months without a precipitating injury, it can also occur after trauma. Pain in the groin and medial thigh, passive external rotation, and restricted range of motion are common clinical findings. However, a pelvic x-ray would show a widening of the joint space and displacement of the femoral head posteriorly and inferiorly in relation to the femoral neck.
Image Description:

Pelvic x-ray (AP)

Slipped epiphysis with femoral neck displaced in relation to the femoral head (green overlay) and widened physis on the left side. The right femoral head and epiphyseal plate show no pathology.
questions.hint: The x-ray of this patient's left hip shows a displaced bony fragment and irregular contour of the femur.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of severe pain in his groin after a fall. Two hours ago, he slipped on a wet rug and fell on his right side. The daughter says he “could not get up on his own” and can hardly walk. Physical examination shows a shortened right lower limb in external rotation; there are no visible bruises. Range of motion of the right hip is severely limited due to pain. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A femoral neck fracture should be suspected in an older individual who presents with groin pain, inability to walk, decreased range of motion, and an externally rotated and shortened leg after a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. Because the fracture site is intracapsular, there is typically little bruising. This patient's x-ray confirms the diagnosis and shows a right-sided femoral neck fracture with complete displacement of the bone fragments. Immediate management of a femoral neck fracture is essential to prevent severe complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head and sciatic nerve injury. In patients < 60 years of age with nondisplaced fractures, open reduction with internal fixation is recommended; patients > 80 years with displaced fractures will require primary arthroplasty, typically total hip replacement.

Key learning point: A femoral neck fracture in elderly patients typically presents after a low-impact fall with groin pain, an externally rotated and shortened leg, and minimal bruising due to the intracapsular location.

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior hip dislocation is typically associated with internal, rather than external rotation of the affected limb and most commonly develops as a result of high-speed trauma (e.g., dashboard injury), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows normal joint congruency between the right femoral head and the acetabulum, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

The dislocated head is closer to the x-ray detector than the contralateral head and is perceived as smaller due to the effect of geometric magnification. In the case of anterior dislocation, the lesser trochanter is typically more visible as a result of external rotation and the femoral head appears larger than the contralateral head.

GT: greater trochanter

C) INCORRECT:

A femoral head fracture typically occurs as a result of posterior hip dislocation due to high-energy trauma (e.g., dashboard injury), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows an intact femoral head, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

Anteroposterior x-ray of the pelvis: A femoral head fracture (green area and green line) in combination with a medial fracture of the femoral neck (angle 75°, Pauwels' classification) can be seen in this x-ray image. This fracture combination (femoral head fracture and medial fracture of the femoral neck) is categorized as Pipkin III according to the Pipkin classification.

D) INCORRECT:

A pelvic fracture typically presents with pelvic instability, local ecchymosis (e.g., in the inguinal, scrotal region), and other findings of concomitant pelvic organ injuries (e.g., high-riding prostate due to urethral injury, hematuria due to bladder injury), none of which are seen here. In addition, pelvic fractures usually occur as a result of high-speed trauma (e.g., due to car/motorcycle accident), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. Lastly, this patient's x-ray shows an intact pelvis, which is inconsistent with pelvic fracture.
Image Description:

The right hemipelvis is displaced superiorly, compatible with disruption of the sacroiliac joint (indicated by dashed lines and double-headed arrow). Bilateral pubic ramus fractures are also present (indicated by arrowheads).

E) INCORRECT:

This was a good option to consider because an intertrochanteric fracture commonly occurs in elderly individuals after a fall on the hip and manifests with an externally rotated and shortened leg, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, this type of hip fracture usually manifests with significant ecchymosis because, unlike in this patient, the fracture site is extracapsular. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows a femoral fracture above the intertrochanteric line, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

AP radiograph of the right hip: Because of the low quality, the structure of the greater trochanter (T) is poorly defined; the dotted line shows a possible contour. A radiolucent fracture gap is located in between the greater and lesser trochanter and at the base of the lesser trochanter (t), possibly indicating an intertrochanteric femoral fracture.
questions.hint: This patient will most likely require total hip replacement surgery.

On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. Moreover, in a patient with pelvic ring fracture, the limbs are usually externally (rather than internally) rotated.

questions.text: You have reviewed x-rays of the pelvis, right hip, and both patellae. The pelvic ring, including the right acetabulum, is intact. The patellae are normal. An x-ray of the right hip shows a posterior dislocation. The femoral neck and shaft on the right side are intact, with no evidence of fracture. Three hours have passed since the collision. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up in two weeks.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation is not recommended in this patient because prompt treatment is required to avoid further complications. Additionally, open reduction is only indicated if closed reduction fails, when the dislocation is associated with femoral neck or head fracture, or if bony fragments/tissue are found within the joint space, and none of these conditions apply.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation is not recommended in this patient because prompt treatment is required to avoid further complications. Although this patient's dislocation needs to be reduced, it should be done as soon as possible and not as an elective procedure.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate treatment is indicated in patients with posterior hip dislocation. Open reduction, however, is only indicated if closed reduction fails, dislocation is associated with femoral neck or head fracture, or bony fragments/tissue are found within the joint space, and none of these conditions apply.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in two weeks is not a recommended strategy because spontaneous resolution is very unlikely to occur. The risk of complications (e.g., osteonecrosis, nerve injury) warrants further treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Emergency closed reduction, usually carried out under procedural sedation, is the recommended treatment for simple posterior hip dislocation. This intervention should be performed as soon as possible (usually within 6 hours) to improve blood flow to the femoral head and thus minimize the risk of complications (e.g., osteonecrosis, degenerative joint disease).

Key learning point: Posterior hip dislocations without associated fractures require emergency closed reduction within 6 hours to minimize the risk of osteonecrosis and other complications.
questions.hint: Posterior hip dislocation requires prompt treatment to avoid further complications.

questions.text: You are seeing an 82-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of severe groin pain following a fall. Two hours ago, he slipped on a wet rug and landed on his right side. His daughter reports that he was unable to get up on his own and can barely walk. On examination, his right lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. There are no visible bruises. Range of motion of the right hip is severely limited due to pain. An x-ray of the pelvis is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A femoral neck fracture should be suspected in an older individual who presents with groin pain, inability to walk, decreased range of motion, and an externally rotated and shortened leg after a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. Because the fracture site is intracapsular, there is typically little bruising. This patient's x-ray confirms the diagnosis and shows a right-sided femoral neck fracture with complete displacement of the bone fragments. Immediate management of a femoral neck fracture is essential to prevent severe complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head and sciatic nerve injury. In patients < 60 years of age with nondisplaced fractures, open reduction with internal fixation is recommended; patients > 80 years with displaced fractures will require primary arthroplasty, typically total hip replacement.

Key learning point: A femoral neck fracture in elderly patients typically presents after a low-impact fall with groin pain, limited hip motion, and an externally rotated, shortened leg, often without significant bruising.

B) INCORRECT:

This was a good option to consider because an intertrochanteric fracture commonly occurs in elderly individuals after a fall on the hip and manifests with an externally rotated and shortened leg, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, this type of hip fracture usually manifests with significant ecchymosis because, unlike in this patient, the fracture site is extracapsular. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows a femoral fracture above the intertrochanteric line, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior hip dislocation is typically associated with internal, rather than external rotation of the affected limb and most commonly develops as a result of high-speed trauma (e.g., dashboard injury), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows normal joint congruency between the right femoral head and the acetabulum, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A femoral head fracture typically occurs as a result of posterior hip dislocation due to high-energy trauma (e.g., dashboard injury), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. In addition, this patient's x-ray shows an intact femoral head, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A pelvic fracture typically presents with pelvic instability, local ecchymosis (e.g., in the inguinal, scrotal region), and other findings of concomitant pelvic organ injuries (e.g., high-riding prostate due to urethral injury, hematuria due to bladder injury), none of which are seen here. In addition, pelvic fractures usually occur as a result of high-speed trauma (e.g., due to car/motorcycle accident), rather than a low-impact fall on the lateral hip. Lastly, this patient's x-ray shows an intact pelvis, which is inconsistent with pelvic fracture.
questions.hint: This patient will most likely require total hip replacement surgery.

questions.text: You are seeing a 25-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision as the restrained driver of the rear vehicle. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. On examination, there is tenderness over both patellae. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with an anterior hip dislocation may present with pain in the groin, and a mild flexion deformity of the hip. However, the leg would be lengthened, externally rotated, and mildly abducted.

B) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ring fractures usually occur following high-energy trauma (e.g., road traffic accident) and may present with hip or groin pain and leg-length discrepancy. However, there is no evidence of pelvic instability, perineal hemorrhage, or swelling on physical examination. Moreover, in a patient with pelvic ring fracture, the limbs are usually externally (rather than internally) rotated.

C) INCORRECT:

A dashboard injury can result in a femoral neck fracture, which manifests with hip and groin pain. A displaced femoral neck fracture also results in limb shortening. However, the leg of a patient with a femoral neck fracture would be either in the neutral position or externally rotated, not internally rotated.

D) INCORRECT:

Femoral shaft fractures usually occur following high-energy trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accidents) and may manifest with shortening of the injured limb and leg pain. However, the pain is usually localized to the mid-thigh, and the thigh would be swollen.

E) CORRECT:

Posterior hip dislocation is the most common type of hip dislocation (approx. 90% of cases) and classically occurs following high-energy trauma, in which a posteriorly directed force (e.g., dashboard during a motor vehicle accident) is directed towards the hip. The affected leg is typically shortened, mildly flexed, internally rotated, and adducted. Given the considerable amount of force required for posterior hip dislocation, associated fractures of the femoral head or the acetabulum are common.

Hip dislocation is diagnosed with the help of an AP view x-ray of the hip. In the case of posterior hip dislocation, the femoral head on the dislocated side usually appears smaller than the normal side, the lesser trochanter may not be visible as a result of internal hip joint rotation, and Shenton's line is typically disrupted.

Key learning point: Posterior hip dislocation typically presents after high-energy trauma with a shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated leg.
Image Description:

Dashboard injuries occur when a force is directed posteriorly towards an internally rotated, flexed, and adducted hip. Potentially resulting damage includes posterior dislocation of the hip; damage to the posterior cruciate ligament of the knee; fracture of the acetabulum, femoral head, or patella; and sciatic nerve injury.
questions.hint: This patient has a typical dashboard injury.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with osteoporosis presents to the emergency department after a ground-level fall. She reports severe groin pain and is unable to bear weight on her right leg. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the right hip region but no obvious deformity or shortening. She has pain with passive range of motion of the hip. Initial X-rays with AP and lateral views of the hip and pelvis appear normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT or MRI of the hip and pelvis
Discharge with analgesia and physiotherapy referral
Obtain ultrasound of the hip joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scintigraphy can detect occult hip fractures, but discharge is inappropriate given the high clinical suspicion for hip fracture.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeat X-rays with different positioning are unlikely to improve diagnostic yield since initial X-rays already included appropriate AP and lateral views of the hip and pelvis, with a combined sensitivity of approximately 90%.

C) CORRECT:

MRI is the preferred imaging modality when an occult hip fracture is suspected despite normal X-rays, as occult hip fractures are present in approximately 40% of symptomatic patients with characteristic clinical features but no visible fracture on initial radiographs. CT can serve as an alternative when MRI is unavailable.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate given the high clinical suspicion for hip fracture based on the patient's presentation of severe groin pain, inability to bear weight, and hip tenderness despite normal initial X-rays.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is not an appropriate imaging modality for evaluating suspected hip fractures and has no established role in diagnosing occult fractures of the hip.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and osteoporosis presents to the ED after a ground-level fall at home. She is unable to bear weight on her left leg. Vital signs are BP, 138/72 mm Hg; P, 92; R, 18; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F). On examination, her left leg is shortened and externally rotated. Laboratory results are hemoglobin, 11.8 g/dL; hematocrit, 36%; sodium, 139 mEq/L; creatinine, 1.0 mg/dL. Pelvis radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Place the patient in skeletal traction until outpatient follow-up
Administer high-dose corticosteroids to reduce inflammation
Schedule urgent MRI to assess for occult fracture
Discharge home with opioid pain medications and instructions for strict bed rest
Admit the patient for operative repair and provide pain control and DVT prophylaxis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skeletal traction is rarely the definitive management for hip fractures and does not address the urgent need for surgical evaluation. Delaying treatment increases the risk of complications such as avascular necrosis and thromboembolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids have no role in the acute management of hip fractures. While inflammation and swelling may occur after injury, the priority is stabilization and surgical planning.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is helpful for suspected occult hip fractures when plain radiographs are normal but clinical suspicion remains high. In this case, the diagnosis is already confirmed as a displaced femoral neck fracture, making MRI unnecessary. This option delays appropriate care.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharging this patient would be inappropriate given the nature of the injury. Hip fractures in elderly patients require inpatient surgical management, and outpatient management risks immobility complications such as pneumonia, pressure ulcers, and venous thrombosis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The standard ED management of a displaced femoral neck fracture in an elderly patient is admission for surgical repair, as this restores mobility and reduces morbidity. Immediate priorities include adequate analgesia, intravenous fluids if needed, and initiation of DVT prophylaxis, given the high risk of thromboembolism in immobilized patients. Delay in surgical management increases the risk of poor outcomes, including functional decline and mortality.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed, head-on motor vehicle collision. He was an unrestrained front-seat passenger and reports severe pain in his left hip that prevents him from moving his leg. His pulse is 110/min, and his blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. On examination, his left lower extremity is held in a flexed position at the hip and knee. The leg appears shorter than the right, with the foot and patella pointed inward toward the midline. Sensation is decreased over the dorsum of the left foot. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior hip dislocation can also result from high-energy trauma, but it manifests with a different limb position. The affected leg is typically held in abduction and external rotation and may appear longer than the contralateral limb. This patient's leg is shortened and internally rotated.

B) INCORRECT:

A femoral neck fracture can occur with high-energy trauma in a young patient and causes severe hip pain and limb shortening. However, the classic deformity for a displaced femoral neck fracture is external rotation due to the unopposed pull of the short external rotator muscles. This patient's limb is internally rotated.

C) INCORRECT:

A femoral shaft fracture results from significant trauma and causes severe pain, swelling, and obvious deformity of the thigh. Although the leg is shortened, the injury is located in the mid-thigh, not primarily the hip joint. This patient's findings are localized to the hip and include a specific rotational deformity.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a posterior hip dislocation, which accounts for approximately 90% of all hip dislocations. The mechanism, a high-energy axial load on a flexed knee (a 'dashboard injury'), drives the femoral head posteriorly out of the acetabulum. The physical examination shows the characteristic limb position: shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The decreased sensation on the dorsum of the foot suggests an associated sciatic nerve injury, a common complication due to the nerve's proximity to the posterior hip joint. This is an orthopedic emergency requiring prompt reduction to prevent avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

E) INCORRECT:

An intertrochanteric fracture is a high-energy injury that causes severe pain, swelling, and shortening of the affected leg. However, the limb is characteristically held in external rotation. The internal rotation seen in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely.
questions.hint: The combination of shortening, flexion, adduction, and internal rotation is a key diagnostic clue.
